intro.title: Intro
intro.content: The project is defined as ORA Web, a small-scale software system for a contract manufacturing company, focusing on integrating contract production data management and efficiency. Case study scope: (Jul 2023 â€“ Aug 2024 Â· Ongoing)

team.title: Team & My Role
clientPoints: Founded in 2019, scaled into one of the leading nutrition contract manufacturers in Auckland.
Acquired in 2025 by a China-listed company.
No in-house design team; I operated as the sole designer in cross-functional delivery.
rolePoints: Led end-to-end UX for ORA Web, from problem framing to workflow design and system structure.
Mapped contract-to-shipment processes and translated operational logic into scalable data and UI models.
Facilitated alignment across Finance, Production Planning, Warehouse/Procurement, and Management.
Worked closely with engineering to ensure feasibility and consistent status logic across views.
team.durationDesc:
Case study scope:
(Jul 2023 â€“ Aug 2024 Â· Ongoing)

scope.title: System Scope
scope.content: This system spans three operational layers across the contract-to-production lifecycle:
points: Decision Makers: They read and consolidated data for timing, risk, and client decisions.
Shift/Planning Managers: They need accurate status and capacity signals to allocate work.
Operators/Executors: They need structured input and clear next-step prompts to keep data reliable.
scope.read: Read: Decide timing and client priorities.
scope.input: Input: Heavy data entry & initial validation.

summary.title: ä»å®ä¹ ç”Ÿåˆ° SaaS è”åˆåˆ›å§‹äººï¼Œæˆ‘ä¸»å¯¼äº†ç«¯åˆ°ç«¯çš„ç”¨æˆ·ä½“éªŒè®¾è®¡ï¼Œå°† 4 ä¸ª Google Sheets è¡¨æ ¼å’Œ Dynamics 365 æ•°æ®æ•´åˆä¸ºç»Ÿä¸€çš„ä»ªè¡¨ç›˜ï¼Œè§£å†³äº†å‰é›‡ä¸» 40 äººå›¢é˜Ÿçš„å·¥ä½œæµç—›ç‚¹ï¼Œå¹¶æˆåŠŸå°†ä»–ä»¬è½¬åŒ–ä¸ºå®¢æˆ·ã€‚
summary.engagement_body: This engagement is a signed Phase 1 delivery for Ora Nutrition: a decision dashboard built on top of production data currently spread across shared spreadsheets.
summary.d365_body: After the client adopted Microsoft Dynamics 365 (D365), Phase 1 scope was defined as a dashboard and decision layer, prioritising D365 as the source of truth instead of rebuilding overlapping data-entry features.
summary.input_gap_body: We are currently confirming whether all required fields can be sourced from D365, or whether ORA Web needs a small input module to capture only the confirmed gaps.

client.title: Client facts
client.name: Ora Nutrition Ltd Â· Contract manufacturer Â· Auckland
client.acquisition: Acquired in 2025 Â· Migrating to D365

role.title: My role
role.ownership: Owned end-to-end UX: workflow mapping â†’ status taxonomy â†’ information architecture â†’ interaction design
role.demo: Produced clickable UI demo to align stakeholders and engineering feasibility

problem.title: Decisions were slowed by cross-sheet verification and status drift across teams.

context.title: Context
context.body: Operational data was maintained in four shared spreadsheets: orders, scheduling, packaging/materials, and finance. The factory has adopted Microsoft Dynamics 365 (D365), but coverage is still incomplete: required fields and status ownership are not yet consistently maintained in one system, so critical updates continue to happen in spreadsheets.

broken_decision.title: What broke decision-making
broken_decision.body: Spreadsheets were used for two purposes at the same time: record-keeping and progress signalling. Teams relied on formatting (colours, borders, notes) to indicate blockers and next actions, but these signals were not standardised across departments. As a result, the same order could show different statuses in different sheets. Before making capacity or priority decisions, managers had to verify what was current by cross-checking multiple spreadsheets.

constraint.title: A structural constraint
constraint.body: Users avoided inserting rows or restructuring tables because of formula break risk. This reinforced workarounds (manual notes and formatting) and made consistent status updates difficult to enforce.

stakeholders.title: Who are the Users Behind the Data?
stakeholders.description: To understand the "why" behind the manual formatting behaviors, I mapped the stakeholders into three engagement layers. This helped me identify exactly who was struggling with what.
stakeholders.graph_title: Mapping the Humans Behind the Data
stakeholders.graph_subtitle: Categorizing stakeholders by their primary interaction with the system.

groups.name: Shift Managers
groups.context: Connecting dots between orders and capacity.

user_voice.title: From Data to User Voice
user_voice.description: While the quantitative data revealed what was happening (heavy manual entry), I needed to understand the why. I traced these patterns back to the specific users to uncover the root friction behind the numbers.

quotes.text: We spend hours analyzing rows just to get a 'vague feeling' of whether we have the capacity to negotiate more orders.
Iâ€™m juggling design, ordering, and clients every day. I simply don't have time to manually fix spreadsheet formatting.
I need to add notes when things change, but Iâ€™m afraid to break the Excel formulas if I insert a new row.
It would be a game-changer if the data was linkedâ€”so I know instantly when materials or packaging actually arrive.
I constantly switch between different sheets just to verify if the information is actually correct.

problem.title: Problem
problem.body: Users had to scroll horizontally repeatedly in Excel to view different data sections , causing inefficiencies, frequent misclicks, and a steep learning curve for less tech-savvy users.

solution.title: Solution
solution.body: We unified all core business data into a single master table to ensure consistency. Role-specific views keep fixed columns visible on the left, while dynamic columns are switchable on the right. To prevent accidental edits from horizontal scrolling, we removed direct in-line editing on the main viewâ€”modifications now require a dedicated action (covered in 'Guide Workflow & Structure Inputs').

how_it_works.title: How it Works
how_it_works.body: A role-tab view lets users switch to their responsible section in one click. The left side keeps fixed common info; the right side only shows current tab-related content. This eliminates horizontal scrolling entirely.

rationale.title: Design Rational
rationale.body: Each user's workflow and responsibilities are fixedâ€”they already rely on left-fixed columns in Excel to track core info, but still face horizontal scrolling headaches with dynamic content. Our role-based tab view builds on this habit: left columns stay fixed to match their existing practice, while tab switches replace scrolling for dynamic content. This aligns seamlessly with daily operations, cuts onboarding costs by requiring no extra training, and eliminates misclick risks from scrolling.

problem.title: Problem
problem.body: Users had to manually cross-check contract changes, as single columns in Excel made it impossible to track updates for specific contracts. Also, Excelâ€™s fixed structure meant they had to put unrelated info in random cells when dealing with temporary or new data. For users with more responsibilities, this meant going through more unrelated data to identify what was relevant.

solution.title: Solution
solution.body: A tab-based, role-specific entry system balancing mandatory core data (proactive payment status/timeline tracking, seamless state transition) and flexible notes, with built-in support for 1-to-many contract-product-material relationships.

how_it_works.title: How it Works
how_it_works.body: Users follow categorized sections, with clear labels guiding step-by-step data entry (e.g., time, status labels like "In Transit"). The system auto-determines contract status: future dates map to "Awaiting Delivery"; if a date passes and the status label remains unchanged, it auto-updates to "Overdue". This lets the system handle oversightâ€”only one entry is needed, and auto-reminders ensure no task is missed.

rationale.title: Design Rational
rationale.body: This design continues our role-based tab approachâ€”once users understand this pattern, they can apply it consistently across all workflows, reducing learning curve. By aligning with their existing habit of categorizing data by role, tabbed pop-up windows let them select input sections without changing entry logic. The core rationale is to solve two key gaps without extra burden: supporting one-to-many relationships (e.g., multiple packages per product) Excel couldnâ€™t handle, and enabling auto-consistent status switchesâ€”all while keeping the interface familiar and cohesive.

moves.headline: Reveal Capacity, Mitigate Risks and Uncover Growth

problem.title: Problem
problem.body: The clientâ€™s factory management relied on disconnected spreadsheets, leading to slow decision-making and difficulty in tracking operational performance, internal process efficiency, and customer order trends.

solution.title: Solution
solution.body:
A daily operational overview module showing real-time factory status and color-coded alerts for metric differences
An internal process optimization module with interactive charts that compare actual and target process time, filterable by production line or order type
A customer order analysis module ranking top clients by volume, plus month-over-month changes and production opportunities for key clients

how_it_works.title: How it Works
how_it_works.body: Upon login, the clientâ€™s factory management team is greeted with the daily focus dashboard by default. Red indicators highlight any issues, and clicking these indicators pulls up detailed information. To switch between different views, simply click the role-tabs at the top. Some modules let users toggle between list view and graph view, while others support filtering by time and production line

rationale.title: Design Rational
rationale.body: To ensure a consistent user experience, we reused the role-tab switcher from previous modulesâ€”placing clear â€œOverview,â€ â€œProcess,â€ and â€œClient Dataâ€ tabs at the dashboardâ€™s top. Users familiar with the system can instantly navigate between views without learning new interactions. For individual widgets, consistent toggle options (list view/graph view) reinforce a unified visual language and cut cognitive load for frequent users

reflection.title: Reflection
reflection.subtitle: Using the Kano Model
reflection.content: In my reflection, I used the Kano model to make sense of the different types of dashboard features:
list: Basic expectations: E.g. being able to see contract status and lead time without digging through spreadsheets.
Performance features: Clearer bottleneck visualization that directly improves planning and internal coordination.
Delighters: For example, exception alerts and narrative views that help managers explain issues to clients.
reflection.content2: By mapping stakeholder requests and existing widgets onto the Kano model, I could:
points: Distinguish between "must not fail" basics and "high-impact" improvements.
Avoid overloading the dashboard with nice-to-have charts that donâ€™t change decisions.
Show that Iâ€™m not only designing UI, but also prioritizing features systematically.
reflection.content3: Including this reflection is my way of demonstrating a growth mindset: Iâ€™m willing to learn, borrow tools from product/strategy (like Kano), and use them to make more grounded design choices.

d1.title: 01. Replace Static PDFs with Live, Date-Aware Catalog
d1.problem: Founder had to manually update Illustrator lookbooks, remove unavailable items, export PDFs, and re-share for every inventory request -- turning simple queries into time-consuming design tasks.
d1.solution: A dynamic catalog link with auto-filtering for date availability and buffer rules, eliminating manual PDF creation entirely.
d1.how: Users receive a shareable link that auto-updates based on selected dates and pre-set buffer periods (for example, a 2-day lead time for returns). No downloads or manual edits -- availability is always current with one click.
d1.rationale: The founder's existing workflow relied on sharing visual assets (lookbooks), so we built on this habit with a familiar link-sharing model. By automating date filtering and updates, we removed the need for manual intervention while keeping the client experience seamless. This cut onboarding to zero and eliminated 42% of admin time instantly.

d2.title: 02. Dual-Notification System
d2.problem: After approving a rental, the founder had to manually draft confirmation emails, attach invoices, and paste tracking linksâ€”repetitive work that delayed client updates.
d2.solution: Every status change triggers two emails: one to the client, one to Ivy. The system becomes both client mailer and founder's assistant.
d2.rationale: Luxury clients expect fast, polished communication. By embedding email triggers into the reservation lifecycle, we eliminated manual drafting while maintaining brand consistencyâ€”turning a 10-minute task into zero effort.

d3.title: 03. Embed Proof Collection
d3.problem: Disputes required digging through personal photo libraries for timestamped packing shots. Trust maintenance became reactive "self-defense" instead of proactive relationship building.
d3.solution: Photo upload required before "Ship" action. Auto-timestamped, centrally stored, attached to client's shipment email.
d3.how: Ivy clicks "Ship" on a reservation. System blocks action until packing photo is uploaded. Photo is auto-timestamped and stored in the reservation record. Client receives shipment email with photo embedded as proof. On return disputes: photo is instantly retrievableâ€”no searching.
d3.rationale: One mandatory step in the existing shipping flow prevents hours of future work. Proactive proof builds trust upfront and frees Ivy from the "proof collector" role.

d4.title: 04. Dual-Scenario Data Persistence and One-Click Sharing
d4.problem: Clients spent significant time selecting products, dates, and entering company details in the live lookbook -- only to face data loss if submission failed (unhappy path) or no easy way to save or share their selections (happy path). This created frustration from wasted effort and extra work for Ivy, who had to re-enter 8% of client requests manually due to lost or incomplete data.
d4.solution: A unified data persistence system that preserves all client inputs (product selections, dates, contact and company info) for both scenarios, enabling one-click sharing of structured data that Ivy can instantly import into the system.

happy_steps: As clients build their request (select products, input details), the system auto-saves progress in real time.
After successful submission, clients get an option to "Save Request Summary" (one-click copy of structured data) for their records.
Ivy receives the request with a pre-populated order form -- no manual data entry required.
unhappy_steps: Client inputs are automatically retained (no page refresh, no lost selections).
A clear alert surfaces with a "Copy Full Request" button, capturing all product choices, dates, and company info as a structured, Base64-encoded string.
Clients share this copied text with Ivy via email or chat.
Ivy pastes the string into the system's "Import Request" tool -- data auto-populates into the order form (products, dates, contact info pre-mapped) with one click, no manual cross-checking.

d4.rationale: The biggest friction point was not just failure -- it was wasted effort, regardless of success. We designed this to eliminate rework entirely: for clients, their time spent selecting and entering data is never lost (whether submission works or not); for Ivy, manual data entry is replaced with instant imports. This dual-scenario value aligns with our core goal of reducing both emotional load (client frustration, Ivy's admin) and operational waste. By turning client inputs into a portable, system-compatible package, we turned potential pain points (failure, follow-up) into efficiency wins -- strengthening trust in the system while cutting Ivy's request-processing time by 80%. The one-click workflow keeps interactions simple for luxury clients (no tech skills needed) and aligns with Ivy's need for streamlined admin.

d1.title: 01. No Checkout Flow
d1.rationale: B2B luxury rentals rely on invoices, deposits, and long-term relationships -- not impulse purchases. Adding payment gateways would add maintenance and friction without reducing admin work. Instead, we automated invoice generation that matches existing client behavior, supporting relationships instead of replacing them.

d2.title: 02. Prioritize Logic Over Custom UI
d2.rationale: With a 12-day MVP timeline, we used reliable base UI components to focus resources on data logic, availability rules, evidence flows, and data persistence. For a solo founder, reliability and correctness mattered more than visual uniqueness, ensuring the system solved core pain points first.

reflection.title: Focus Over Features: Designing for Human Priorities
reflection.body: A critical takeaway is that digital transformation should not prioritize completeness -- it should protect human strengths. Initially scoping for a full-featured platform, we pivoted to focus solely on eliminating creative drain by absorbing repetitive, low-judgment tasks. This showed that aligning technology with the user's core value (design, in this case) delivers more impact than adding unnecessary features. It also reinforced that trust (not just efficiency) is a designable outcome -- proactive proof collection, reliable availability data, and dual-scenario data persistence all strengthened client relationships while freeing the founder's creativity. The data persistence design, in particular, highlighted that solving for wasted effort (not just failure) creates disproportionate value for both users and the business, turning potential frustration into loyalty.
